data.title: Jeans for Genes
data.meta_description: I‚Äôm rocking my jeans this year for Jeans for Genes! I‚Äôll be hosting an event to raise funds to help cure childhood genetic diseases. 1 in 20 kids faces a birth defect or generic disease, like cancer, cystic fibrosis, and life-threatening metabolic disorders. That‚Äôs 12 kids born every minute worldwide. Please support my event by making a donation today ‚Äì thank you! üíô
data.text:
Why I‚Äôm doing Jeans for Genes

I‚Äôve signed up to Jeans for Genes to raise money for Children‚Äôs Medical Research Institute and help save more kids‚Äô lives. Can you help by sharing this message with the people you know and asking them to donate too?

Here's just one story explaining why this cause is so important:

Harrison was a healthy, active child, until one day out of the blue, ‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt quite right, and then the next day he just stopped walking, and we knew something was very wrong,‚Äù said his father, Adam.

Doctors found something wrong with his blood, and when his parents were told it could be leukaemia ‚Äúeverything stopped.‚Äù As terrifying as that word was for them to hear, it got worse as Harrison‚Äôs case was unique, and it took many DNA tests to determine he had acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). They were lucky to get the right treatment after the right diagnosis, but it could have gone very differently if that work had not been done.

‚ÄúMedical research is so important to get any answers for any genetic condition,‚Äù said his mum, Naomi. ‚ÄúFor Harrison, the research done prior to him getting sick is what helped save our son. Research needs to continue so the next child diagnosed with a rare form of AML or any cancer‚Äîit can help them.‚Äù

I care about the 1 in 20 Aussie kids who face a birth defect or genetic disease, like cancer. Most people don‚Äôt know that cancer is caused by changes in genes‚Äîbut almost everyone will be touched by it. So, the research you and I support today may one day help someone we know, someone in our family.

There‚Äôs lots of work to do, but there is also lots of hope.
